awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Conceptualizing a Quantum Information Bioscience Institute for Quantum Sensing and Simulations in Novel Hybrid Architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.
 
This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the theme of the intersection of biological systems and quantum science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided funding for the conceptualization of a Quantum Leap Challenge Institute focused on quantum biosensing and simulations in novel hybrid architectures.

Intellectual Merit: The main goal of this project was to assess via workshops, brainstorming activities, and virtual meetings whether non-trivial quantum processes in biomolecules could be exploited for quantum information purposes, for storing, sensing, and controlling quantum information, and whether quantum sensing mechanisms could be exploited to sense biological processes.

We gathered a research community from biology, quantum information science, chemistry, engineering, and quantum biology interested in the proposed conceptualization project. The resulting outcomes highlighted that before quantum biological processes are ripe as building blocks for ready use in quantum information processing, a deeper understanding of the biophysical mechanisms that allow biomolecules to exploit quantum phenomena in complex environments is an essential requirement before proposing new strategies for sensing, storing, and controlling quantum information.

One crucial step toward understanding biophysical mechanisms that allow quantum effects to be exploited for biological functions, would be the integration of current imaging and spectroscopy methods with current quantum sensing tools for achieving enhanced sensitivity in vitro and in vivo.  The inclusion of quantum noise spectroscopy methods would further enhance the signal-to-noise ratio.  

One of the big challenges is the design of biomolecular aggregates as new quantum sensing devices, which could be injected in cells and tailored to follow and sense specific biological pathways, such as spin-dependent biochemical reactions or photoactivated signaling. Such quantum biosensors could also shed light on the role of heat transfer and intracellular electromagnetic fields in biological processes, and thereby in various diseases.

Another crucial step is understanding which degrees of freedom could be used to store and transduce energy. Certain vibronic manifolds, ubiquitous in biological environments, may serve as ideal candidate degrees of freedom to be exploited for both storing and transducing energy between electronic and mechanical degrees of freedom.

On the theoretical side a big challenge is understanding how the measurement problem in quantum mechanisms affects our ways of observing biological systems with quantum mechanical methods. For this, we have explored nonlinear extensions of the Schrodinger equation and Rovelli's relational quantum mechanics, as well as QBism and other interpretations that allow for perspectival realism and the role of the observer in (interactive) measurement. Further explorations are needed to construct an adequate quantum theoretical framework tailored for hierarchical biosystems.

 

Broader Impacts: This project laid the groundwork for an extensive national and international network of collaborations to form an ecosystem that bridges the quantum and biological sciences. Discussions among biologists, chemists, physicists, mathematicians, and engineers on topics at the interface between the biological and quantum sciences have been fostering the development of a common language, cross-disciplinary experimental and theoretical tools, and pedagogical methods that would benefit future scientists of the quantum biosensing community. Moreover, the development of projects on quantum sensing for biological applications will certainly impact the biological sciences with downstream applications in the biomedical fields. Finally, our development of a diverse community of researchers, trainees, and students starting from the K-12 level has nurtured a future pipeline from communities largely underrepresented in the quantum sciences.
